content.body: sure, but in the same sense as flatMap itself is `.reduce((out, ...args) => out.concat(mapper(...args)), [])`
content.formatted_body: sure, but in the same sense as flatMap itself is .reduce((out, ...args) => out.concat(mapper(...args)), [])

content.body: Hi! I just noticed that `Atomics.multiply()` isn't a thing. Is that because for all other operations you don't need to know whether the type is signed or unsigned but for multiplication you do?
content.formatted_body: Hi! I just noticed that Atomics.multiply() isn't a thing. Is that because for all other operations you don't need to know whether the type is signed or unsigned but for multiplication you do?

content.body: What objects in 262 use option bags?
I am investigating whether error.cause's HasProperty + Get pattern is standard or unusual
262 itself does not tend to use object bags much, though that's changing. 402 uses them more and just does Get, IIRC
I think we are in generally in favor of just doing Get; I argued for error.cause to be a special case because, unusually, `undefined` is a value one might reasonably want to use
content.formatted_body: I think we are in generally in favor of just doing Get; I argued for error.cause to be a special case because, unusually, undefined is a value one might reasonably want to use

content.body: In cases where `undefined` is not an expected value there's no particularly reason to do a Has check first
content.formatted_body: In cases where undefined is not an expected value there's no particularly reason to do a Has check first

content.body: Hmm
I do not like distinguishing between undefined and not-present in the options bag
As well as on the object itself
I feel like if you really want to split hairs there you should use error.cause === undefined vs. error.cause === null, instead of testing 'cause' in error

The problem is that the error values are generally being handed to you, not a thing you are given yourself: that is, you are writing `catch (e) { throw new Error('message, { cause: e })` without testing the value of `e`
content.formatted_body: The problem is that the error values are generally being handed to you, not a thing you are given yourself: that is, you are writing catch (e) { throw new Error('message, { cause: e }) without testing the value of e

content.body: * The problem is that the error values are generally being handed to you, not a thing you are creating yourself: that is, you are writing `catch (e) { throw new Error('message, { cause: e })` without testing the value of `e`
content.formatted_body: * The problem is that the error values are generally being handed to you, not a thing you are creating yourself: that is, you are writing catch (e) { throw new Error('message, { cause: e }) without testing the value of e

m.new_content.body: The problem is that the error values are generally being handed to you, not a thing you are creating yourself: that is, you are writing `catch (e) { throw new Error('message, { cause: e })` without testing the value of `e`
m.new_content.formatted_body: The problem is that the error values are generally being handed to you, not a thing you are creating yourself: that is, you are writing catch (e) { throw new Error('message, { cause: e }) without testing the value of e

content.body: Sure
But I don't understand why that means it's important that `'cause' in new Error('message')` is false whereas `'cause' in new Error('message', { cause: undefined })` is true.
content.formatted_body: But I don't understand why that means it's important that 'cause' in new Error('message') is false whereas 'cause' in new Error('message', { cause: undefined }) is true.

content.body: Ah, this was on the assumption that there would not be a `cause` property if you didn't pass the options bag at all
content.formatted_body: Ah, this was on the assumption that there would not be a cause property if you didn't pass the options bag at all

content.body: that is, I think it's important that `'cause' in new Error('message', { cause: undefined })`, since you are explicitly asking to create an error with a `cause`
content.formatted_body: that is, I think it's important that 'cause' in new Error('message', { cause: undefined }), since you are explicitly asking to create an error with a cause

content.body: I don't know if I have an opinion about whether `'cause' in new Error('message')` should also be true
content.formatted_body: I don't know if I have an opinion about whether 'cause' in new Error('message') should also be true

content.body: but I do think `'cause' in new Error('message')` should match `'cause' in new Error('message', {})`
content.formatted_body: but I do think 'cause' in new Error('message') should match 'cause' in new Error('message', {})

content.body: My opinion is it should also be true
I.e. we should not branch behavior on {} vs. { cause: undefined }
Filed https://github.com/tc39/proposal-error-cause/issues/35
Mind, it's already stage 3, so I don't know how much appetite there will be for this sort of change
it's also already shipping
well, almost, coming up in chrome 93

> What objects in 262 use option bags?

Temporal uses options bags in almost every method that takes parameters. If we're using them incorrectly or inconsistently, let us know!
content.formatted_body:
What objects in 262 use option bags?

Temporal uses options bags in almost every method that takes parameters. If we're using them incorrectly or inconsistently, let us know!

content.body: My intent was for this to be "implementer feedback" as we work to spec/implement structured clone for it
i was chatting with marja on the V8 team about just this the other day, on whether we should unify option bag handling to be Get for Error cause

my conclusion was that "just a Get" should be the default behavior for option bags, but once in a while a specific use case arises that requires special casing with a Has, like Error cause has with wanting to capture undefined/falsy values, which can be thrown
wait, is that what's being discussed here, i might've skimmed it too fast
Pretty much yeah. I just think we shouldn't distinguish because { cause: undefined } and {}
From a documentation standpoint, does `{ cause: null }` mean "I am filling `cause` but I don't know what the cause was" as opposed to `{ cause: undefined }` which means "I didn't fill in a `cause`"?
content.formatted_body: From a documentation standpoint, does { cause: null } mean "I am filling cause but I don't know what the cause was" as opposed to { cause: undefined } which means "I didn't fill in a cause"?

content.body: are you asking about the status quo or domenic's suggestion?
the status quo is `cause`, if present at all, is honored, since you can `throw undefined;` and maybe you want to capture that in the `cause`
content.formatted_body: the status quo is cause, if present at all, is honored, since you can throw undefined; and maybe you want to capture that in the cause

content.body: it seems hostile to future options for `new Error(message, {})` to create a `cause` property that would not be present on the result of `new Error(message)`
content.formatted_body: it seems hostile to future options for new Error(message, {}) to create a cause property that would not be present on the result of new Error(message)
